text:
Subalternation is a relation between either a pair of [[Affirmative]], or a pair of [[Negative]] [[Categorical Propositions|Categorical Proposition]]. In any of these two cases, the first statement in the pair is [[Universal]], and the second one is [[Particular]].

The distinctive feature, that sets [[Subalternation]] apart from all other relations in the [[Traditional Square of Opposition]], is that it is //unilateral// - you can't swap two propositions.

If the [[Universal]] proposition is known to be //True//, then the [[Particular]] one __must also be //True//__.

If the [[Particular]] proposition is known to be //False//, then the [[Universal]] one __must also be //False//__.



|Universal Statement|Particular Statement|
|{{ALL Statement!!.prs.venn-aristotelian}}|{{SOME Statement!!.prs.venn-boolean}}|



or



|Universal Statement|Particular Statement|
|{{NO Statement!!.prs.venn-aristotelian}}|{{SOME ARE NOT Statement!!.prs.venn-boolean}}|



If a pair of [[Propositions|Categorical Proposition]] use the same [[Terms|Term]], in order to have [[Subalternation]] relationship they must either be  [[A|ALL Statement]] and [[I|NO Statement]] propositions, or [[E|NO Statement]] and [[O|SOME ARE NOT Statement]] propositions respectively.

In order for the [[Subalternation]] relationship to hold, the [[Propositions|Categorical Proposition]] must have [[Existential Import]], i.e. this relationship is only meaningful if we assume the existance of the [[Subject]] in reality. 

Thus, the Subalternation relationship is a feature of [[Aristotelian|Aristotelian Logic]] and not [[Boolean|Boolean Logic]] logical system.

Since [[Boolean Logic]] doesn't have [[Existential Import]], in it's framework the relationships between the [[A|ALL Statement]] and [[I|NO Statement]] statements and [[E|NO Statement]] and [[O|SOME ARE NOT Statement]] statements are [[Undetermined]].

''Examples:'' 

//'All men are corrupt'// vs //'Some men are corrupt'//. 

//'No men are corrupt'// vs //'Some men are not corrupt'//.

If the first statement is //True//, then the second statement must be //True//; if the second statement is //False//, then the first statement must be //False//.
